subject: Perl Books Collection
header: Do you have Perl books collection?

I am sure most of us, do own the Camel book. As we know, there are hardly any new Perl book published in recent years. I recently bought two very popular Perl books "Extending and Embedding Perl" and "Network Programming with Perl". I realised there are two distinct views about good old Perl books. One view is that the recommendations in these books are no longer in use, since we have better choices available on CPAN now. I fully agree to this view but I also agree to the other view that it is still relevant in terms of base knowledge of the subject. Above all, there is a sentimental values attached to each Perl book that I own.

Last week, Gabor, spoke about learning language in the editorial. Being, an Indian by birth, I know more than just the national language of India, Hindi. I can understand, to be precise, 6 human languages. Now a days, I am learning Spanish from my daughter as she is learning part of her school curriculum. But here I would like to know how many programming languages one can fluently code in. Recently in The Weekly Challenge contest, we have received loads of solutions in different languages. In the week 147, we received 100+ solutions. One member stands out in the crowd is, Abigail, who have contributed in 30 different programming languages. To me, it is impossible but he did it.

How many programming languages I know? Well thanks to the weekly challenge, I got the opportunity to code in Raku, Python, Java and Swift as well as Perl, ofcourse. Do you want to try some new language, please give it a try.
Enjoy the week and stay safe.

entries.text: Do you like Perl::Critic but you can't use it against your legacy codebase because it reports too many problems? Then you should try this new module and share your experience with the author.

entries.title: Call for Papers, Perl & Raku Conference in Houston 2022

entries.text: The Perl & Raku Conference is a high-quality, inexpensive, technical Conference that celebrates the family of Perl programming languages. Do submit papers if you are keen to give talk.

chapters.title: The Weekly Challenge
chapters.header: The Weekly Challenge by Mohammad Anwar will help you step out of your comfort-zone. You can even win prize money of $50 Amazon voucher by participating in the weekly challenge. We pick one winner at the end of the month from among all of the contributors during the month. The monthly prize is kindly sponsored by Peter Sergeant of PerlCareers.

entries.author: mohammad_anwar
entries.text: Welcome to a new week with a couple of fun tasks "Fibonacci Digit Sum" and "Largest Square". If you are new to the weekly challenge then why not join us and have fun every week. For more information, please read the FAQ.
entries.title: The Weekly Challenge - 149

entries.author: mohammad_anwar
entries.text: Enjoy a quick recap of last week's contributions by Team PWC dealing with the "Eban Numbers" and "Cardano Triplets" tasks in Perl and Raku. You will find plenty of solutions to keep you busy.

chapters.title: Perl Tutorial
chapters.header: A section for newbies and for people who need some refreshing of their Perl knowledge. If you have questions or suggestions about the articles, let me know and I'll try to make the necessary changes. The included articles are from the Perl Maven Tutorial and are part of the Perl Maven eBook.
